The government has no resources to implement activities or actions that train people in the proper management of forest resources or alternative land uses to compensate for their basic needs in harmony with the sustainable use of natural resources.
Training captains and women through regional workshops in 2016 and 2017 enhances management of production projects, supporting food self‑sufficiency.

The 2015 training workshop for Indigenous facilitators equipped local authorities and young people with GIS management skills and increased awareness of forest protection, strengthening community stewardship.
Ongoing fire surveillance and community training prevent high‑impact forest fires, safeguarding the project’s conservation outcomes.
The Family Agrifood Production Units system produced 4,000 tons annually and trained 800 students.
The project area is legally protected, and communities are trained on rights.
Training and socialization activities in the Indigenous Reservation have been monitored, ensuring dissemination of project results and strengthening community governance.

Students enrolled in technical programs related to the Sustainable Integrated Management System of Forest and Land of the RIU‑SM have been certified, supporting capacity building.

O5.sentence: The compensation for environmental services for avoided deforestation has been managed.
It has managed the compensation for environmental services for avoided deforestation.

Activities, value in USD, and verification report: VCS Version 4.0. A1.1: Monitor and control the conservation and recovery of forests and lands. A1.2: Develop and implement a system of communication and information. A1.3: Develop and implement a governance system for the development and sustainability of ACATISEMA Association. A2.1: Establish and develop a Family Agrifood Production Units System. A2.2: Design and develop a training program plan for the administration and management of natural resources of the RIU-SM. A2.3: Manage resources for project design and establishment of production. A3.2: Verify the project and register units of forest compensation for avoided deforestation. The following executed budget was presented (Annex 2.2 of Monitoring Report 2018 & 2019).
Once the Project Area (PA) is approved by the VCS, carbon credits will be traded.

Each year a budget is established for the activity of verifying the project and registering forest compensation units for avoided deforestation, providing the economic capacity to cover the costs and expenses of this activity and any additional events that may arise.

It aims to manage the lands and forests of this region by establishing measures to reduce vulnerability to external agents, setting self-sustaining production systems, and managing a funding mechanism.

A3.2: Verify the project and register units of forest compensation for avoided deforestation (471,783 units, 9.9%); total 4,783,840 units, 100.0%. The following executed budget was presented (Annex 2.4 of Monitoring Report 2018 & 2019).

The compensations received for environmental services provided by preventing deforestation and contributing to the conservation of RIU‑SM forests are invested in benefits for the indigenous peoples of RIU‑SM through the budgetary execution of the REDD+ Project RIU‑SM.
To finance the project during 2016 and 2017, a private investor was brought in through a Participation Account Agreement worth COP 1,200,000,000 (USD 400,000).

Additionally, while the project will incur ongoing costs related to management and implementation of project activities—including forest patrols, social programs, and payments for environmental services—it will not generate future financial benefits other than VCU-related income.
Strategic partners have supported important forest governance processes (Activity A1.3) and helped cover some administrative costs of the project, such as Fundación Natura (Annex 1.10.2.4).
The project proponents shall improve the mechanism with the aim of all communities agreeing on benefit sharing.
A validated mechanism for valuing and compensating environmental services has been designed, enabling the registration of forest compensation units that contribute to avoiding deforestation.
Compensation for avoided deforestation is managed and invested in benefits for indigenous peoples.
The project established a family agrifood production system, a financial mechanism for environmental service compensation, and a local valuation system.
The project area is not registered in any other carbon trading scheme, ensuring that carbon credits are only generated from this project and preventing double counting.

R4.sentence: Mitigation: Indeed, the project generates overall positive impacts on the social and economic aspects of the communities, who derive their livelihoods from productive activities performed in the region around the project area and leakage belt.
